title: Aging and Estrogen Status: A Possible Endothelium-Dependent Vascular Coupling Mechanism in Bone Remodeling
background: Postmenopausal osteoporosis involves pronounced bone resorption linked to estrogen deficiency. Vascular mechanisms may influence bone remodeling through endothelial factors like nitric oxide and blood flow regulation. Aging and estrogen loss may impair endothelial function in skeletal circulation, contributing to bone loss.
objective: To examine endothelium-dependent vasodilation and trabecular bone volume in young and old female rats with different estrogen statuses to investigate potential vascular coupling mechanisms in bone remodeling.
methods: Young (6-month) and old (24-month) female Fischer-344 rats were divided into six groups based on intact status, ovariectomy (OVX), and estrogen replacement (OVX+E2). Femoral principal nutrient arteries (PNAs) were isolated for vasodilation assessment using acetylcholine with/without inhibitors. Trabecular bone volume was measured via microCT. Estrogen levels were controlled and measured via ELISA.
results: In young rats, OVX diminished vasodilation and bone volume (43% reduction), both restored with estrogen replacement. In old rats, OVX did not affect vasodilation, but estrogen replacement enhanced both parameters (28% bone volume increase). Strong correlations existed between vasodilation and bone volume in both young (R²=0.641) and old (R²=0.671) rats. Estrogen replacement improved vasodilation to similar levels (~90%) in both age groups.
conclusion: Estrogen status has parallel effects on vascular endothelial function and bone volume, providing evidence for a coupling mechanism where endothelium-dependent vasodilation may influence bone remodeling in aging and estrogen deficiency.

learning_notes.note: The study demonstrated strong correlations between endothelium-dependent vasodilation and trabecular bone volume, with R² values of 0.641 in young rats and 0.671 in old rats, suggesting a vascular coupling mechanism in bone remodeling that operates independently of estrogen's direct effects on bone cells when estrogen levels are low.

Age-dependent responses to ovariectomy were observed: young rats showed 43% bone volume reduction after OVX, while old rats were unaffected, indicating that baseline age-related estrogen decline may mask additional OVX effects in aged animals.

Estrogen replacement restored vasodilation to approximately 90% in both young and old OVX rats and increased bone volume by 28% in old rats, demonstrating that exogenous estrogen can improve vascular function and bone parameters even in aged animals with pre-existing declines.

Methodologically, the study used femoral principal nutrient arteries pressurized to 44 mmHg and warmed to 37°C, requiring spontaneous tone development, with vasodilation assessed using acetylcholine and specific inhibitors (L-NAME for NOS, indomethacin for COX) to isolate signaling pathways.

The research revealed that aging impairs endothelium-dependent vasodilation primarily through nitric oxide pathways, as age-related differences were abolished by NOS inhibition, and responses to direct NO donors did not differ among groups, indicating endothelial rather than smooth muscle dysfunction.

Estrogen replacement altered vasodilation signaling mechanisms, shifting from primarily NO-mediated to include endothelium-derived hyperpolarizing factor components, suggesting estrogen modulates multiple endothelial signaling pathways that may influence bone perfusion.

Plasma estrogen concentrations differed significantly between age groups, with young intact rats having median 62 pg/ml compared to 25 pg/ml in old intact rats, providing physiological context for the observed age-related differences in vascular and bone responses.
